column1: Will Narendra Modi be appointed to a second consecutive term as prime minister of India after the 2019 general elections?
column6: ['Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
column11: Narendra Modi, the leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), has served as prime minister of India since 2014 (The Economist, Inter-Parliamentary Union). General elections for the Lok Sabha are due to be held in April and May 2019 (Aljazeera). If no prime minister has been appointed by 1 October 2019, the question will be closed as no. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

Prime Minister Modi has been presented as a strong leader in India that has governed since 2014. Many people are in support of him as he head to the general elections. However, there are those people who would see him no longer in power, for his government has been stated as the most corrupt and ineffective government that India has ever had. In fact, many blame him for the dire state of the Indian economy. In the end, I think that it will be close, too close to call as this point, but if I had to predict the likelihood of Prime Minister Modi being in power after the elections, I would say that yes there is a chance.

It seems pretty clear that the NDA is weaker this time than last. With the exception of Bihar, it's hard to see where they are materially stronger than last time. And even there, considering they won 31 out of 40 seats, it's likely not to lead to a spike in won seats. Meanwhile, across the Hindi belt, they should face significant challenges, especially in UP, where they're facing a two-way fight from the INC, which is focusing on upper-caste voters, and the BSP-SP which is focusing on Dalits, OBCs and Muslims.
He is the New controller of world.

Modi and the BJP have seen a spike following the Balakot air strike where those polled were 14% more likely to support Modi if they heard about the Balakot air strike. While unemployment is the largest concern for Indian voters, national security has also, at times, top the charts, and continues to sway voters, which stands to benefit the Hindu nationalist BJP. The most conservative polls predict that the BJP will hold 267 seats, while the Times Now-VMR projects 279.
All polling suggests that this is most likely, at the very least they are likely to be the majority in a coalition government

With Modi winning the 2014 general election on a platform of transforming India's economy and hardening India's defense stance against Pakistan. Since then India's economy despite being one of the fastest growing in the world, has stalled and suffered from its smallest growth in years. As for his defense stance Modi, has been a hardliners, and took defensive action during the Kashmir Crisis and has continued to justify attacks across Pakistan's border to attack terrorist groups. Regardless, Modi is still likely to be appointed prime minister of India running on the same platform. He appeals to the large portion of India's right wing population due to his hard stance on security and defense and is using his past reputation of being hard on Pakistan and terrorist organizations from Pakistan to rally support. Along with that he is appealing to young voters by promising a regrowth of the economy and a greater number of jobs.
It seems as if the people of India are content with his leadership. I have not seen any negative media coverage regarding his policies

I just realized there is very little marginal reward for being right if you give a very high probability. But there is a very large negative score if you are very sure but wrong. I'm going to reduce risk exposure by staying closer to the middle, i.e., 30-70% probabilities. If you predict something to have greater than an 80% chance you better be right or it will severely hurt your Brier score. That's the nature of the squared function.

When looking solely at polling estimation data for the 2019 general elections in data, it is evident that Modi has an edge over other candidates. Polling data shows 62% support for Modi and only 32% support for the next runner-up, Rahul Gandhi (1). From this data alone Modi seems to be the obvious choice of the Indian population with very weak opposition. Additionally, the approval ratings for Modi have been very high throughout his time in office. The approval percentages have ranged from 88% to 63% throughout his first term as Prime Minister (2). This further cements his position, making it easier for him to win against competitors. Modi's current policy and global trends also increase the likelihood of his re-election. For example, Modi's policies have generally leaned towards populism and nationalism for the Indian people (3). Given the current global trend for nationalist leaders and sentiment, it would be likely that he be re-elected. Lastly, Modi's recent confrontation with Pakistan, India's long term rival, has boosted his approval ratings and has made him a very appealing choice for those in India. (4)

Modi's approval ratings have risen following the 'vicotry' over the conflict with Pakistan in February (1). Modi will likely remain in power because rather than choosing an entirely religious platform, his campaign platform is one of nationalism. This message unites the some of the ideologically different Hindu populations as Modi is not seen as an ideologue nor does he appear to "pamper the minorities" (2). There are, however, still several economic questions that Modi must address. Unemployment in India is rising and the country's youths are moving into cities for education and job opportunities. Unfortunately, there is a shortage of jobs, so there are more qualified individuals than there are vacancies. In rural parts of India, support for Modi is expected to stay strong because communities have benefited from cheaper cooking gas and electricity, as well as access to toilets and more schools (3). Another sign pointing towards Modi's expected success is the global trend of growing nationalism. While the opposition party in India has some support, the power of that party (called Congress) remains within one family - the Gandhi's. The public has resisted this form of contemporary monarchy (in more countries than just India), and have responded with the election of nationalist leaders, such as Modi. 1. https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/post-pulwama-pm-narendra-modis-ratings-rise-by-7-to-52-poll/articleshow/68350217.cms 2. https://www.bbc.com/news/resources/idt-sh/Modis_India 3. https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/324025

There’s a good chance of re-election for Modi, since his party won by large margin in 2014. He is running on a Hindu nationalist platform, which can inspire passion, and he has incumbent advantage. His base is the largest demographic in India (the country is 80% Hindu), and he has significant funding. There are a couple other factors to take into account, however. We can’t really say that because he did well in the first election he will do well in the second since his platform has changed, (the 2014 campaign was based off job creation and economic development) and he made a bunch of promises that some feel he hasn’t kept - there’s unhappiness over agrarian distress, unemployment, demonetization, the Ayodhya temple. A lot will depend on his response to the attack in Kashmir - it seems like he’s taking a strong approach which will satisfy his base but cause division, if people feel that he handles it poorly there is a greater potential that he will lose the upcoming election.

Tuan Huynh, Singapore-based chief investment officer and head of discretionary portfolio management for emerging markets at Deutsche Bank Wealth Management:

The Carnegie Endowment for Peace has consolidated scholarship on the Indian voter, deducing that the Indian voter tends to vote based on identity rather than economics, as is usually the case with the American voter (https://carnegieendowment.org/files/understanding_indian_voter.pdf). PM Modi remains incredibly popular, with a most recent poll putting his approval rating at 74% (https://www.livemint.com/Politics/GR5CA3625Va9MVtjdSTeaI/Narendra-Modis-approval-ratings-stay-high-at-74.html). That said, economic issues have recently trended towards popularity over social issues. CEP further found that Modi and the BJP remain heavily popular amongst non-Muslims in India, and the recent Kashmir attack is sure to stoke tensions.

Indian elections often flip back and forth, but Modi begins in a position of dominance, though it has been weakening significantly. The odds are extremely good that the BJP will win a plurality, but highly unlikely that they win a majority. In other words, the real question is can he put together a coalition in which he's the lead? The NDA base coalition should provide at least another 30 seats, but it's probably 52/48 or so that that's enough. My guess, though, is that the independent parties would give him a majority if he won a strong plurality.

The Opposition parties to the ruling BJP party have united in key regions and this will significantly hamper the BJP's prospects in key states that they won in the last elections. The biggest drop will be in the states of UP 2014 (BJP won 71 out of 80 seats), Rajasthan (25 out of 25 seats), MP (27 out of 29 seats), Gujarat (26 out of 26 seats). Update to my previous analysis: Correlation between NDA seats and UPA seats • In an earlier analysis, I estimated distributions for the amount of seats we can expect each party to receive. These distributions, as with all mathematical models, were simplifications of reality. In this update, I address one simplification – the fact that seats lost by NDA might go to UPA. Here I’m mostly looking at the elections 1991 – 2014 (before that, BJP hadn’t really gained momentum). Also, I’m looking at coalitions rather than parties – the reason is simply that I have already produced models for coalitions, not for parties. • There’s a strong correlation between INC and BJP seats (0.933). Taken together, the two coalitions take, on average, 78% of seats. • So we can think about the election in this way – imagine a world where INC starts with 100% of seats. Then the election involves people going in and casting their votes, and for each non-NDA vote, we subtract a seat from NDA. On average, 78% of votes subtracted from NDA in this way will be assigned to UPA. The other 22% will be assigned to the non-coalition parties. • In my earlier analysis, I arrived at the following distribution for the NDA seats we can expect at the next election. (I did create two distributions for NDA, but after analysing state polls, I’m wary of using poll data.) NDA ~ N(258, 542) • So if we model NDA as above, we can model UPA as dependent on NDA. Simply, NDA takes 78% of the seats that NDA does not get: UPA = (543 – NDA) * 0.78 • In this model, I’m going to assume that a coalition with more seats will win the election. This is an oversimplification of how minority governments form, but it’s approximately correct – and good enough for the model. Where NDA wins 238 seats, UPA wins 238 seats. Where NDA is more successful, UPA is less successful, vice-versa. So, if NDA has more than 238 seats, NDA will form government, and where NDA has fewer than 238 seats, UPA will form government. • (Note: In this model, there’s no real need to model majority governments and minority governments separately.) • So the steps from here are simple: all we have to do is, using the NDA distribution above, calculate the probability that NDA will win 238 or more seats. This probability (you can calculate using a spreadsheet) is 64.44%. • The probability changes very little if you play around with the total % of seats taken by the two coalitions. • So which of my approaches is better? This captures a part of reality that my previous analysis does not catch – although it has its own simplifications, it feels better than my previous analysis. The exception would be the economic factors in my previous analysis. So I want to apply equal weights to a) this analysis and b) my economic model from before, but no weight to c) poll data or d) my distribution model from before. That puts the probability of NDA forming government at the mean of 64.44 and 69.29%, which comes out to 66.87%.

bumping up a bit after reading this positive write-up re the Indian economy for 2019, though I'd say the wild card remains crop prices https://www.businesstoday.in/current/economy-politics/general-elections-us-dollar-strength-and-oil-prices-to-direct-rupee-report/story/305390.html

Going to go a bit lower than consensus - I don't think India is the easiest place to poll, we don't have a lot of polls to begin with, and the last set of elections were not especially favourable for the BJP, though that won't necessarily translate to the next general election. A lot of fairly random economic factors could spell serious trouble for Modi: vide this story about widespread discontent amongst farmers due to low onion prices https://www.indiatoday.in/india/story/onion-farmers-prices-maharashtra-narendra-modi-2019-lok-sabha-elections-1418772-2018-12-28. It may sound trivial to Western ears, but as the article notes, this sort of thing has a big track record of turning out to be the difference-maker in prior Indian elections. India is also a big oil importer and quite vulnerable to a sudden spike in oil prices, should that occur between now and April/May. He's the clear front-runner, but a few factors combine to pull me down towards 50% vs the crowd

The December state election results notwithstanding, the BJP and Modi have built a strong election machine and given the results in many other election in the last few years I think Modi wins another term.
The December state elections are telling and I think Indians as a whole think they can do better, considering the corruption charges and slow of economic growth.

Overall, the BJP will get a boost from the government’s achievements in raising the living standards of 220 million poor families by providing toilets, electricity, cooking gas and banking facilities, Shah said.
He is incredibly popular in India, and even though the BJP popularity is going down a bit, he will still get it.
